footnotes.footnote: Uncontracted form of ες-stem's ε + ending. See Smyth 292 and 292 D
where -εέ- (the stem's ε and the initial ε of the ending) contract w/o the rest of the ending joining in the contraction. See also 292 D.
All adjectives said to be of the "1st Declension" = α- Declension feminine unless noted otherwise.
Compound adjectives in -ης not accented on the last syllable show recessive accent (noyt on the ending) in the contracted forms. See Smyth 292 c.
See Smyth 288. There are no truly regular feminine adjectives in this Declension, but some regular "Adjectives of Two Endings" and some irregulars.
See Tables in Smyth 290 for uncontracted forms of 1st and 2nd Declensions (in parenthetheses)
ε-stem contracts of the α- Declension

Consonant Declension Adjs w/ a separate form for the feminine ...--Smyth 294. In adjs w/ stems ending in ντ- , that "ντ-" becomes "σσ-" before those endings, w/ "α" lengthened to "η" in the oblique cases --See Smyth 299.
ε-stem contracts of the o- Declension

The most common "endings" of the nominative case of these "3rd declension" adjectives are not really endings at all, but a lengthening of the vowel before the final consonant of the stem (e.g. "-ων-"for the stem ending in "-ον-", "-ωρ-"for the "ορ-"stem, and "-ην-"for the "εν-"stem)
See 293 d. Accusative Plurals of Comparatives borrowing the Nominative form
All masculines, "feminines" and neuters said to be of the "2nd Declension" are o- Declension adjectives unless noted otherwise
See Smyth 297 for uncontracted stems in υ
